Holding: Enterprise can be proven through association-in-fact with common purpose
Pattern requires at least two predicate acts with continuity showing ongoing criminal activity
Case_Citation: H.J. Inc. v. Northwestern Bell 492 U.S. 229 (1989)

Holding: Forfeiture of proceeds from racketeering activity mandatory under 18 U.S.C. § 1963
Case_Citation: United States v. Vampire Nation 451 F.3d 189 (9th Cir. 2006)

Holding: Each use of mail or wire in furtherance of scheme constitutes separate predicate act
Case_Citation: United States v. Fernandez 388 F.3d 1199 (9th Cir. 2004)

Holding: Member liable for reasonably foreseeable acts of co-conspirators in furtherance of conspiracy
No formal organizational structure required - informal association sufficient for RICO enterprise
Case_Citation: United States v. Riccobene 709 F.2d 214 (3d Cir. 1983)

Holding: Four-year statute of limitations begins when plaintiff discovers or should have discovered injury
RICO conspiracy requires agreement to commit two or more predicate acts - does not require commission of predicate acts
Statements by co-conspirator admissible under FRE 801(d)(2)(E) if made during and in furtherance of conspiracy
Base offense level determined by most serious predicate offense under USSG § 2E1.1
Case_Citation: United States v. Persico 645 F.3d 85 (2d Cir. 2011)

Holding: Bona fide purchaser for value without knowledge can assert interest in forfeited property
Case_Citation: United States v. Fleet 498 F.3d 1225 (11th Cir. 2007)

Holding: Venue proper in any district where enterprise operated or where predicate acts occurred
Case_Citation: United States v. Cauble 706 F.2d 1322 (5th Cir. 1983)

Holding: Defendant must know enterprise engaged in pattern of racketeering but need not know all details
Case_Citation: United States v. Shifman 124 F.3d 31 (1st Cir. 1997)

Holding: Money laundering under 18 U.S.C. § 1956 qualifies as RICO predicate act
Case_Citation: United States v. Genova 333 F.3d 750 (7th Cir. 2003)

Holding: All RICO enterprise participants jointly and severally liable for treble damages under 18 U.S.C. § 1964(c)
Case_Citation: Steamfitters Local Union No. 420 v. Philip Morris Inc. 171 F.3d 912 (3d Cir. 1999)
